b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:39): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: it seems to me that it's not a requirement to use an XML parser for text/html.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:41): just like you can with XHTML today
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (12:41): If not a requirement, at least a goal
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:41): even if browsers do some weird crazy hacky thing instead of using an XML parser
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:41): but never mind what they do, because you can just use XML
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:41): the recent wikipedia case shows how hard that is
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (12:42): That's only because browsers sabotage it on purpose
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:42): but I concede that that's a goal. I meant it isn't a requirement to make browsers process text/html using an XML parser.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (12:43): I think XML Core has sabotaged &nbsp; in XML on its own
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:52): The goal seems to be that everything is XML+colons+URIs and that tag soup is a dim and forgotten memory
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:52): But the goal is not necessarily achievable :)

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:05): And they might have tediously coded every instance by hand
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:06): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Do you really think that streamability is essential in XML5 under error conditions?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:07): So you couldn't go back and adjust, say, the attributes on a previous element
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:07): If you can't support streamability under error conditions, you can't support it at all
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:08): I think the worst problem is that you close the root element and find start tags after
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:08): since you'll have already streamed the output before you found the error condition
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:08): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I meant supporting only the kind of error correction where the parser has a fixed finite amount of internal state
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:08): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: You can require streaming parsers to stop, like HTML5 does
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:09): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: and anything the parser reports to the app has been committed to
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:09): I'm envisioning the HTML5 tokenizer
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:09): and a tree builder that commits to its actions on a per-token basis
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:10): even if the resulting fixups can't be as fancy as the AAA or foster-parenting

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:10): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: It seems bad to design a language so that people have to choose between performance (streaming) and robustness (non-streaming, error-correcting) and non-conformance (streaming, error-correcting-in-a-different-way)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:11): as far as I can tell, the main problem is that if you happen to close the root element, all the subsequent non-comment tokens have to be discarded
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:11): (of course, PIs should be tokenized as PIs)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:11): but I'd be inclined to kill the internal subset
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:12): (which are the three choices the validator.nu SAX parser offers)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:12): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: It depends how much worse the error correction has to be to support the SAX case
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:12): For the web the sax case seems less important because typical UAs are required to build trees anyway
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:13): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: XML content doesn't have fancy legacy fixup requirements
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:13): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: I don't expect XML5 parsers to ever work as general-purpose text/html parser
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:13): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Sure. I don't know in practice how big the tradeoffs are you would have to make to get streaming support
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:13): since you'd want an XML5 parser support non-html root elements
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:14): Would offloading parsing into a separate thread become much easier if the parser was streaming?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:14): basically the rule is this:
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:14): if you get a start tag, create and insert the element
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:14): if you get an end tag, and there's a matching start on the stack, pop up to and including the latest start
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:14): if not, ignore the end tag

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:14): But given something that dealt gracefully with more errors vs something that supported streaming it is not obvious to me that streaming should always win for all values of "more" and "gracefully"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:15): and once root is closed, throw away non-comment tokens
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:15): then there's the issue of needing a non-Draconian Namespace layer on top of this thing

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:16): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: It sounds like you can't do that with a fixed finite amount of internal state, since you have to maintain an unbounded stack of open elements
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:17): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: true. the stack is allowed to be infinite
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:17): I suppose you could put it behind an XML firewall that prevents DOS attacks by limiting the nesting depth
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:18): The stack size is limited to input size / 3 at least :)
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:18): What do you do on EOF with non-empty stack?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:19): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: pop the whole stack
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:19): i.e. generate endElement callbacks for each stack item
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:19): What about the last text node, is that emitted?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:20): Seems kind of brittle if the input can be truncated

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:20): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: How would you define "gracefully"? Would it be something like: consider a list of errors people make when producing XML (weighted by likelihood), and work out what output they wanted, and the error correction is more graceful if it gives that output?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:20): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Something like that
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:20): rather than just being the simplest thing that doesn't abort and doesn't lose all subsequent data when there's any error
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:21): I was thinking of this from the POV of never throwing a fatal error and then just taking the simplest tree-builder-level recoveries
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:21): and using HTML5 tokenizer behaviors just in order to be able to copy and paste code
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:22): in fact, I once made a parser like this just in order to measure the cost of the HTML5 tree building part
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (13:23): Priority of constituencies :)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:23): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: A fatal error isn't any better for users than a stray </html> near the top of the page causing the rest of the page to vanish
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (13:25): Exception: Don't emit the root element close tag until EOF, even if you see it earlier
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:25): It seems more non-draconian if you at least keep all the text content; e.g. ignore root element close tags entirely
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:26): I thought it was a requirement not to change the parser output for doctypeless XML 1.0 documents
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (13:26): Nobody's going to notice if comments-after-root-element change :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (13:27): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: people who write CSS whitespace handling test case notice changes in getting trailing ws getting hoisted into root element
